perez-almendros-etal-2022-pre.title: Pre-Training Language Models for Identifying Patronizing and Condescending Language: An Analysis
perez-almendros-etal-2022-pre.author:
Perez Almendros, Carla  and
Espinosa Anke, Luis  and
Schockaert, Steven
perez-almendros-etal-2022-pre.paperMotivationText: The task of recognizing Patronizing and Condescending Language (PCL) remains understudied in NLP and is a challenging problem due to the subtle nature of its language, limited availability of datasets and the need for commonsense knowledge.
perez-almendros-etal-2022-pre.paperContributionText: The authors study to what extent PCL detection models can be improved by pre-training them on other, more established NLP tasks, including three tasks from the ETHICS dataset.
perez-almendros-etal-2022-pre.paperResultsText: They find that performance gains are indeed possible in this way, but improvements depend on the task used for pre-training. Pre-training on tasks related to sentiment, harmful language and commonsense morality are particularly helpful.
perez-almendros-etal-2022-pre.dataOtherText: situation-assertion pairs, sentences about social justice, assertions about morality
perez-almendros-etal-2022-pre.resourcesOtherText: StereoSet (Nadeem et al. 2020), Offensive Language (Zampieri et al. 2019), Hate Speech (Basile et al. 2019), Hyperpartisan News Detection (Kiesel et al. 2019), Democrats vs. Republican Tweets, Irony Identification (Van Hee et al. 2018), Sentiment Analysis (Rosenthal et al. 2017)
